>>15070524
Off the mark Anon. The game never ceased. It simple shifted. When the environment change and survival depends on securing the basics; Food, safety, shelter - the dealer runs a positive-sum game. Social beings, humans included, generally achieve better hunt and survival chances as individuals when acting in concerted action. The thing is however, scurrying and scrambling to escape predators or find food and stay dry stopped being a problem round abouts 60-40k years ago when we decided towns and tribes of more than 30-150 smelly relatives were a good idea. Fast forward a bit and the positive-sum game is history, so what's the problem? Well, the game doesn't end untill the last complex organic molecule in the world toss a pair of snake eyes, it's just that the rules periodically change while the game is session. The players are never told when this happen, they usually discover the rules the hard way when it cost them their seat at the table. A few short millenia ago the rules changed and the game changed from blackjack to poker. Now they're not competing against the dealer, they're competing against their former partners. The positive-sum game turned into a zero-sum game.
From a proliferating construct's perspective the absence of growth constraints means it's limited solely by the proliferation of the competitors who occupy the same space. That's why we got so smart. That's why we have this grotesquely overdeveloped lump of gray goo in our skulls consuming an absurd share of our energy. The only cases runaway overadaptation occurs in nature is when a selection criteria is both unceasingly applied and the pressure grow at a rate that matches the organism's iterative and constantly improving adaptations over generations - like when the selection criteria is both a survival dependency and a mirror image of yourself - your fellow man and the society you both depend on to thrive.
You're not overshooting shit, you're just off-target.

>>15070085
[math]\mathbf{Theorem.}[/math] There are infinitely many primes.
[math]\mathbf{Proof.}[/math]
Base case: There are infinitely many primes greater than n.
Induction step: There are therefore infintely many primes greater than n-1.

And so on, until you reach n=0. But 0 is not a prime, contradiction. Therefore there are infinitely many primes. [math]\qed[/math]

posts.com:
The natural numbers are countable.
Every infinite subset of a countable set is countable.
The prime numbers are a infinite subset of the natural numbers.
Therefore, the prime numbers are countable.
Since both the natural numbers and the prime numbers are countable, they possess the same cardinality.
Q. E. D.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15070212
The blades don't bend because of centrifugal force, they are rigid because of centrifugal force. If you lose that centrifugal force in flight, the blades will break off. The R22 manual says this blade stall occurs at 80% plus 2% per thousand feet of density altitude. Different for different machines. Basically:
>Centrifugal force gives the blades their STRENGTH in flight.
>Bernoulli's Principle and Newton's Third Law creates the force which lift the blades (and helicopter)
If you lose that centrifugal force with the weight of the helicopter on them, they will flap up until they are, uh, mechanically separated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15070212
Maybe this guy puts it better than I do.

>As lift on the blades is increased (in a takeoff, for example), two major forces are acting at the same time—centrifugal force acting outward, and lift acting upward. The result of these two forces is that the blades assume a conical path instead of remaining in the plane perpendicular to the mast. This can be seen in any helicopter when it takes off; the rotor disk changes from flat to a slight cone shape.

>If the rotor rpm is allowed to go too low (below the minimum power-on rotor rpm, for example), the centrifugal force becomes smaller and the coning angle becomes much larger. In other words, should the rpm decrease too much, at some point the rotor blades fold up with no chance of recovery.

The height of your lipase level has very little correlation to the severity of your pancreatitis, it really just matters that it was elevated to slap a diagnosis on you. In all likelyhood it won't happen again, so don't worry about it too much

posts.name: Anonymous

>>15065692
>The Sun appears to be unique in that it's very quiet, magnetically, compared to other stars in its reference class. The average magnetic noise of Sun-like stars is 150% of our Sun's. This is important because too much magnetic activity will sterilize a star's surrounding planets. On the other hand, expulsion of charged stellar material slows the star's rotation down due to conservation of angular momentum so if this "stellar magnetic breaking" is too LOW, then the mass of the star doesn't decline over time and thus the orbiting planets experience orbital decay. Ideally, a potentially life bearing planet's orbital decay will be perfectly counterbalanced by the decline in its parent star's mass to keep the orbit stable. This relationship is so rare that there are less than a thousand such cases in the entire Milky Way.
Most of those Sunlike stars (.5% of all stars) don't behave like our Sun. Within that .5% group of stars, our Sun stands out.

But everyone somehow realizes that this is not a proper thing to do, one sacrifices truth and rigor in favor of freedom.
Just like physics should not "do what it wants" by inventing mythical stories with no correspondence with reality, and should study the natural world, mathematicians likewise must study the phenomena of natural numbers without invoking abstract unjustified philosophy and theology into it.

>Disagree. That might have seemed natural in the 19th century but it is too restrictive
Cohen, Godel and other set theorists have shown using inner models and forcing that the notion of a set is too vague to refer to a definite concept, its "meaning", if there is one, can be altered by various methods without altering the truth of any of the axioms, and the resulting concepts seem rather symmetrical - there is no reason to prefer one over the other. And even these concepts are not definite themselves, you can keep branching to specify them more and more, in a way that decides more and more set theoretic propositions one way or the other.
Nothing of the sort is the case with natural numbers. There is one and only one notion of natural number, definite in its specification, and one that schoolchildren study and understand. That is, starting from 0 and keep adding 1 more, obtaining an unending/infinite sequence we all know and love.

Natural numbers and nothing else is the object of intuition proper. Every mathematical object intuitively accessible to us in the sense of Kronecker has been demonstrated to reduce to natural numbers. If you understand something precisely, you can encode it on a computer. Real numbers have never been encoded on a computer, because they are a convenient fiction, and computers only understand precise reality. The proper place for real numbers as a concept is in philosophy journals, not mathematics. The category of philosophy would be "what if there was an infinite mind which could hold infinite sequences of digits with infinite information and perform infinite manipulations with them at will". It's an interesting philosophical concept, but when supposed mathematicians go from propositions about real numbers to infer something about the natural numbers, there is a problem because their methods are unreliable and have in the past lead to contradictions. Philosophy should not infringe on mathematics.

>>15070488
There are several issues with your post.
It is not accurate to say that natural numbers are the only objects of intuition. While natural numbers are certainly a fundamental concept in mathematics, there are many other concepts and objects that are intuitively accessible to us, such as geometric shapes, algebraic equations, and more.
The statement that "real numbers have never been encoded on a computer" is simply false. Real numbers can be encoded on a computer using various numerical representations, such as floating-point numbers. These representations may not be able to perfectly represent all real numbers, but they are still used extensively in computing and have proven to be highly useful and reliable.
The claim that real numbers are a "convenient fiction" is not supported by the evidence. Real numbers have a well-defined mathematical structure and have been used successfully to model a wide range of phenomena in many different fields.
The suggestion that real numbers should be confined to philosophy journals rather than being studied in mathematics is misguided. Real numbers are a fundamental part of modern mathematics, and they have played a crucial role in the development of many important mathematical concepts and results.
It is not true that the use of real numbers has led to contradictions in mathematics. While it is true that there are certain limitations to the use of real numbers, these limitations have been well-understood for many years and do not negate the usefulness or validity of real numbers as a mathematical concept.

Explain what precisely differentiates our "natural language" from a "formal" one and why proofs "done in natural language" are preferable. Explain why you perceive a calculus of deduction as unprefered. Also elaborate on how you perceive the process of "understanding".

For the record, the ancients and the medievals had concerned themselves with small numbers of argument schemas gathered more or less ad hoc. Aristotle's syllogisms give twenty-four schemas, of which Aristotle himself mentions nineteen. The watershed between classical and modern logic lies in 1847, when George Boole published a calculus which yielded infinitely many valid argument schemas of arbitrarily high complexity (Boole [1847; 1854]). Today we know Boole's calculus as propositional logic. I do not understand what the issue is with using his calculus as a formalization of a part of our natural language, namely the one concerning propositional sentences.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15070479
The claim that the notion of a set is too vague to refer to a definite concept is not supported by the evidence. While it is true that set theory, like any other branch of mathematics, is built on a foundation of axioms and definitions, these axioms and definitions are carefully chosen to provide a precise and well-defined foundation for the subject. Set theory is a highly developed and well-understood branch of mathematics, and it has proven to be a valuable tool for understanding a wide range of mathematical concepts.
The idea that the "meaning" of a set can be altered without altering the truth of any of the axioms is not accurate. While it is true that different models of set theory can be constructed that satisfy the same axioms, these models are not all equally valid or useful. In fact, some models of set theory are known to be inconsistent or otherwise problematic, and they are not considered to be viable foundations for the subject.
The suggestion that natural numbers are more "definite" than sets is not supported by the evidence. While natural numbers are certainly a fundamental concept in mathematics, they are not more "definite" than sets in any meaningful sense. Both natural numbers and sets are well-defined mathematical objects that have been studied extensively and have proven to be highly useful and important in the field.
The claim that set theory is somehow less "real" or less valuable than other branches of mathematics is not supported by the evidence. Set theory is an important and widely studied branch of mathematics that has played a crucial role in the development of many important mathematical concepts and results. It is a highly respected and well-established part of the mathematical landscape, and there is no reason to view it as less "real" or less valuable than other branches of the field.

posts.com: Yes, that's actually a common symptom of adhd

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's normal to feel more motivated to do tasks that you find enjoyable or meaningful, and to feel less motivated to do tasks that are tedious or mundane. This is true for everyone, not just people with ADHD.

It's also normal to feel more motivated to do tasks when you have a clear sense of purpose or when you feel a sense of accomplishment after completing them. On the other hand, tasks that feel pointless or lack purpose can be demotivating.

For people with ADHD, it can be especially challenging to maintain motivation for tasks that are routine or require sustained attention. This may be due to the way that ADHD affects the brain's ability to regulate attention, emotion, and behavior.

If you find that your lack of motivation is interfering with your ability to complete important tasks, it may be helpful to work with a mental health professional to identify strategies that can help you stay motivated and manage your ADHD symptoms. Some strategies that may be helpful include setting clear goals, breaking tasks down into smaller steps, using rewards or incentives to motivate yourself, and finding ways to make the task more enjoyable or meaningful. It may also be helpful to work with a therapist or coach to develop coping skills for managing the challenges of ADHD and to learn how to better regulate your emotions and behaviors.

>>15068587
It's good because it scares the poor baby technophobia. Even if 99% of their spewings are ramblings they attract enough attention that the 1% semi-legit apprehensions get debated. There are things that need to be sorted out legislation and human rights-wise that have been problems for some time and will only grow bigger. For example their schizo ravings about Elon musk mindcontrolling them with brainchips they cribbed from Deus Ex. While they exaggerate absurdly a valid and realistic concern is information interface utilities in phone RRS apps and social media. These platforms are immensely popular and are to a laughably minor extent regulated and audited by impartial sources. Laying down the precedent this decade will save us a lot of headache in the the future. Also it will force legislation governing intercorporate compatibility and functionality accountability. Currently our governments are behind the curve and more or less operate on a general basic consumer rights level. Money back, replacement product, sub 10 year support guarantees etc... That shit cannot fly when technological devices become as indispensable and irreplaceable as basic utilities and civil protection services. We're already seeing this to some degree with electronic currency exchanges on a consumer level and digital citizens services (in many countries, applying for licenses, permits, healthcare information and insurance is already overwhelmingly a self-serve digital process). These technologies are on the way to becoming protected and strictly legislated utilities - even when the service is provided by private companies. This is in many ways a disadvantage to the corporate providers. They have to expend more capital to fulfill requirements mandated by law. An analogue can be seen in the power grid suppliers. The emergency generators, safety measures, redundancy facilities and black start plants are an immense cost to these corporations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15062774
>How long do you give yourselves before skipping exercises?
I try to do the harvard putnam problem of the day every day.
Sometimes I'll spend a few hours beating my head against the wall until I get somewhere.
Usually if I'm doing book exercises, I skip the easy problems (ones where I can do a rough sketch of the solution in my head) and only focus on the tough problems.
I am confident I can grind out number crunching and basic algebraic manipulation so once I can tell that is all a problem is, I skip it.

If you are first learning the material, just try to get comfortable with the concepts to the point you know them by heart or could just re-derive them if you forget the exact details.
The easy first problems are usually just for familiarization with concepts. The harder problems are usually to let you figure out which tricks to use.

I'm more interested in the essence of a problem. Whenever a clever trick is required is what I like. I try to identify what properties of the problem might be useful for forming a heuristic that tells me when I should consider the particular type of trick.

[eqn]

[/eqn]

posts.com:
smooth solution
[eqn] We consider the Navier-Stokes equations in 2D in vorticity-stream function form:
\begin{align*}
\frac{\partial \omega}{\partial t} + u \frac{\partial \omega}{\partial x} + v \frac{\partial \omega}{\partial y} &= \nu \left( \frac{\partial^2 \omega}{\partial x^2} + \frac{\partial^2 \omega}{\partial y^2} \right) + f \
\frac{\partial \psi}{\partial x} &= -\omega \
\frac{\partial \psi}{\partial y} &= u \
\frac{\partial u}{\partial x} &= -\frac{\partial \psi}{\partial y} \
\frac{\partial v}{\partial y} &= \frac{\partial \psi}{\partial x}
\end{align*}
where $\omega$ is the vorticity, $\psi$ is the stream function, $u$ and $v$ are the velocity components, $\nu$ is the kinematic viscosity, and $f$ is the external force.

We seek a solution $(\omega, \psi, u, v)$ that is smooth and bounded on the domain $\Omega = [0, L_x] \times [0, L_y]$. We introduce the norms
\begin{align*}
| \omega |\infty &= \max{(x,y) \in \Omega} |\omega(x,y)| \
| \psi |\infty &= \max{(x,y) \in \Omega} |\psi(x,y)| \
| u |\infty &= \max{(x,y) \in \Omega} |u(x,y)| \
| v |\infty &= \max{(x,y) \in \Omega} |v(x,y)|
\end{align*}
and
\begin{align*}
| \omega |2 &= \left( \iint\Omega |\omega(x,y)|^2 dx dy \right)^{1/2} \
| \psi |2 &= \left( \iint\Omega |\psi(x,y)|^2 dx dy \right)^{1/2} \
| u |2 &= \left( \iint\Omega |u(x,y)|^2 dx dy \right)^{1/2} \
| v |2 &= \left( \iint\Omega |v(x,y)|^2 dx dy \right)^{1/2}
\end{align*}
to measure the smoothness and boundedness of the solution.

We can rewrite the Navier-Stokes equations in the following form:
\begin{align*}
\omega^{n+1} &= \omega^n + \frac{\Delta t}{2} \left( L_1(\omega^n, u^n, v^n)
[/eqn]

Hey lads, I have a math related question. Here in Denmark we have a tradition of eating vanilla rice porridge with cut almonds, but one of them is whole and whoever has it in their dish it receives a prize (usually some chocolate). And each year, we have the same damn question of *if* there is an optimal spoonful to have the best odds of getting the whole almond.

For the sake of ease, I'll just rephrase this question to simplify it:

>>15068602
IF the cards are truly randomly distributed, then every time someone takes a card they have exactly 1/10 chance of getting an ace. So there is no optimal draw. Your only hope is that the cards may not be truly random, so that the order makes a difference. For example, maybe the whole almond is heavier and more likely to be near the bottom, so it is better to wait near the end. But that is a physics question.

>>15066203
You are simply thinking about it too hard.
[math] i [/math] is simply defined to be the solution to: [math] x^2 + 1 = 0 [/math]. Initially it was just a trick to solve cubic equations (see https://youtu.be/cUzklzVXJwo) but it turns out they have some very nice properties; to be more specific, they form a [math] \textit{field} [/math], which basically means they share a lot of properties with standard real numbers and don't behave weirdly unlike a number system which say, would have a solution to [math] 0 x = 1 [/math]. This is why we define a solution to the former but not to the latter (except in special cases, see Riemann sphere). In application, complex numbers often reduce a problem to a very easy one (see for example, fast fourier transform). There's not much else to it.
The whole graph thing is just a visualisation but one way to think about it is that: in a number line multiplying by [math] -1 [/math] is essentially rotating 180 degrees, so multiplying by [math] i [/math] should be rotating by 90 degrees since [math] i^2 = -1 [/math]

Oh you want a logical definition? Then why didn't you say that first, anon. How silly of me! Okay here goes.

Assume ZFC holds.

Then define [math] \mathbb N = \{0,1, \dots \}[/math] to be the following:
[math] 0 = \emptyset\\ 1 = 0 \cup \{ 0 \} \\ n + 1 = n \cup \{ n \} [/math]
where [math] n + 1 [/math] is the number after [math] n [/math].
Define [math] S : \mathbb N \to \mathbb N, n \mapsto (n+1) [/math].
Define [math] + : \mathbb N \times \mathbb N \to \mathbb N [/math] to be a binary operation such that: [math] a + 0 = a, a + S(b) = S(a+b)[/math].
Define [math] \times : \mathbb N \times \mathbb N \to \mathbb N [/math] to be a binary operation such that: [math] a \times 0 = 0, a \times S(b) = (a \times b) + a [/math].
We call the set [math] \mathbb N [/math] along with the operations [math] +, \times [/math] the semiring of natural numbers.

Define [math] \mathbb Z [/math] as an equivalence class of pair of natural numbers the following way:
[math] (a, b) \sim (c,d) \iff a + d = b + c[/math]
Using [math] [(a,b)] [/math] to denote the equivalence class containing [math] (a,b) [/math], we define addition and multiplication as:
[math] [(a,b)] + [(c,d)] := [(a+c, b+d)] \\
[(a,b)] \times [(c,d)] := [(ac+bd, ad+bc)] [/math]
We call the set [math] \mathbb Z [/math] along with the operations [math] +, \times [/math] the ring of integers.

Define [math] \mathbb Q [/math] to be an equivalence class of pairs of an integer and a non-zero integer the following way:
[math] (a, b) \sim (c,d) \iff ad = bc [/math]
Addition and multiplication is defined as follows:
[math] [(a,b)] + [(c,d)] := [(ad + bc , bd)] \\
[(a,b)] \times [(c,d)] := [(ab, cd)] [/math]
We call the set [math] \mathbb Q [/math] along with the operations [math] +, \times [/math] the field of rationals.

cont.

A subset [math] A [/math] of the rational numbers is called a cut if it possesses the following three properties:
[eqn] A \neq \emptyset \land A \neq \mathbb Q \\
r \in A \implies A \subseteq \{q \in \mathbb Q : q < r \} \\
r \in A \implies \exists s \in A \; r < s [/eqn]
Define [math] \mathbb R [/math] to be the set of all cuts in [math] \mathbb Q[/math]. Given [math] A, B \in \mathbb R[/math] define addition and multiplication in the following manner:
[eqn] A + B = \{ a + b : a \in A \land b \in B \} \\
A \times B = \{ a b : a \in A, b \in B, a, b \geq 0 \} \cup {q \in Q : q < 0}
[/eqn]
We call the set [math] \mathbb R [/math] along with the operations [math] +, \times [/math] the field of reals.

Define [math] \mathbb C [/math] to be the set of pairs of members of [math] \mathbb R [/math].
Addition and multiplication is defined as follows:
[eqn]
(a,b) + (c,d) = (a+c,b+d) \\
(a,b) \times (c,d) = (ac − bd, ad + bc)
[/eqn]

There! Hope that helps anon.

If you multiply two vectors where the "y-coordinate" is represented as a multiple of i, and the x coordinate as a multiple of 1, its the same as adding the angles and multiplying the magnitudes. For example, (1 + i) * (2 - i) = (3 + i) when you multiply it out. You can draw out these three vectors and verify that (1 + i) has an angle of 45 degrees, (2 - i) has an angle of around -26 degrees, and (3 + i) has an angle of about 45 - 26 = 19 degrees.

If you still think this is still schizo shit, then ask yourself why multiplying a positive number by a negative number yields a negative number. This isn't really a tangible operation either, unless you consider 1 and -1 to be vectors following the same multiplication logic. The vector of 1 has an angle of 0, -1 has an angle of 180, multiply the two and you get a vector of angle 0 + 180 = 180. This would of course be -1. And if you multiply -1 by itself, you get a vector of angle 180 + 180 = 360 (or 0), which is 1 again. By the same token, multiply i (a vector that's 90 degrees with a magnitude of 1) by itself and you end up back with -1, since 90 + 90 = 180.

Consider the euclidean plane and draw a Cartesian coordinate system. Any point in space will hence have a pair of coodinates (x,y). Now give (1,0) the name 1 and (0,1) the name i, you can check they satisfy the usual rules of algebra.

posts.com:
>>15068806
> how they got the 1/2c part
Using eqn 3, then eqn 2 becomes:
[math](\partial_t + c\partial_x) u = (\partial_t + c\partial_x) \dfrac{1}{2c}\int\ h(s)\ ds[/math], where [math]s = x+ct[/math]

[eqn]
\dfrac{1}{2c} \int \left( \dfrac{\partial h}{\partial t} + c\dfrac{\partial h}{\partial x} \right) ds =
\dfrac{1}{2c} \int \left( \dfrac{\partial h}{\partial s} \dfrac{\partial s}{\partial t} + c\dfrac{\partial h}{\partial s} \dfrac{\partial s}{\partial x} \right) ds = \\
\dfrac{1}{2c} \int \left( \dfrac{\partial h}{\partial s} c + c\dfrac{\partial h}{\partial s} \right) ds = \dfrac{1}{2c} \int 2c \dfrac{\partial h}{\partial s} ds = h(s)
[/eqn]
which proves eqn 3 is a solution.

> how they got u(x,t) = f(x+ct) + g(x-ct)
The general solution is the combination of each independent solution. Note that either bracket in eqn 1 can be zero, eqn 2 is only the +ve sign, the -ve gives you g using the same method as above.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15069745
The action (or Hamiltonian or whatever) has a global symmetry. The ground state of the system doesn't have that symmetry. However there are many ground states and the symmetry transformation transforms between them so there is no contradiction

If that's not what you're confused about get better at asking questions

posts.name: Anonymous

How do I unorder it?
Does [math] 3 \sum_{i \neq j} x_i^2 x_i = 3 \cdot 3 \sum_{i < j} x_i^2 x_j [/math]? Since there are 3 ways of arranging with 2 like elements.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15070447
It doesn't make sense to have an ordered sum since the two factors have different powers. For instance on the left side there are terms like x_2^2 x_1 that don't appear on the right side if you try to index the sum like i<j

For your last term in your previous post involving x_i x_j x_k what you are trying to do makes sense, and after you order it i<j<k you'll get a factor of 6 from the 6 permutations of three elements.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Milkwaukee Tool is actually just a brand name for some chinkshit company so unless you relocate to China you'll never be hired by them.

Regardless, there's plenty of tool mfgs that want competent workers. Mostly CAD designers and machinists but there's others. The type of work depends on the region but honestly, any competent assembly tech or tool designer will be an actual capital T toolmaker who can make 3x the money building car engines or car engine tools. Most of these people (barely) passed Community College so your Cornell degree in MechE will be way, way, waaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaay overkill for 90% of these applications. The other 10% you'll meet at your school's job fair/networking group masturbation event.

As for pay/expectations the highest paid guys are in the chip fabs making the lithography vats (for the lack of a better term) that physically etch computer chips. This is the sort of job Cornell would want you to take as it's very prestigious and respectable. It's also an EE job not a MechE job.

>>15065994
Emailing profs is for anglo universities as far as I know. European institutions usually advertise their PhD projects on their websites. You apply via the website and send a cover letter, transcripts and other documents. The only exception to this is Switzerland I think. I know for EPFL, you apply to the program first, and then if they accept you, you have a year to find an advisor. That's when you start emailing. ETH also sometimes asks for applications to programs as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15066850
Exactly as you said. Basically tell them
1. Who you are.
2. That you want to work with them.
2. Very briefly, why you are interested
3. What draws you to their work
4. Here's why I think I would be a good fit. CV attached.

The key is getting noticed. If you have an introduction you should use it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15067611
>Also, does anyone have experience with online course certificates?
Unless your university offers credit for online courses taken at specific sites or offered by specific institutions, they're worth just as much as reading a book about a subject or watching a tutorial video series on YouTube made by Pajeetra Smellyeeth, which is to say, they can be used for the sake of casually dropping the fact that you've got some level of acquaintance with the subject, but might have absolutely no validity as far as academic credentials go.
If you're majoring in Applied Math, you'll most likely come across the same subjects you'd get a brief, somewhat shallow overview of in Discrete Math, like symbolic logic, set theory, graph theory, and combinatorics. Bear in mind that, regardless of what you major in, you will always have to work for somebody or make something for somebody else (be it a research institution, a non-specialized customer, or employees from a large corporation), so you'll inevitably have to deal with the human interactions factor. I hate it too, and would much rather do my own thing for myself, but it's what we all gotta do. Professors have to both write papers for academic journals and prepare classes for their students. People who work on mathematical models have to come up with presentations and explanations for the use of various mathematical functions that are used to model a certain type of phenomenon (be it physical, hypothetical, economic, etc.). People who make software have to code stuff with a broad end-user category in mind.
If you'd rather get an applied math major right now, and would honestly not mind having to do self-training for either heading into the engineering or software development worlds, then it wouldn't necessarily be the worst decision in the world. It's not really that hard to teach yourself how to develop software programs once you've got some strong bases in procedural logic. No clue about finance though.

Things like interfacing or embedded work, where your software interfaces to hardware and real world events. Benjamin Reubinoff began the project to overcome barriers facing investigations of sex differences in humans. Currently there are two major ones: the difficulty of separating chromosomal and hormonal effects and the inability to pinpoint the effects of X and Y chromosomes while ruling out contributions from the rest of a person's genetic makeup. "The main reason for doing this study was the lack of a good model to study differences between males and females in humans," Reubinoff says. It absolutely does have volume. Take any immersion of the Klein bottle into R^3, then do a partition of unity thingy, 1 = sum_i lambda_i(x).
Each patch is diffeomorphic to a region in R^2, and as such it has volume. I.e. if the region is parametrized as t_i(x,y) i=1,2,3, then the volume is
[math]\int_{R \subset \mathbb{R}^2} \lambda_i(x,y) ||\frac{dt}{dx} \times \frac{dt}{dy}|| dxdy[/math]

The occult has always been riddled with hand wavy metaphors that lack any sort of mathematical backbone from which we can nourish its foundations until every work can be tied back to physics. These have been posted before, but there is no harm in doing it again.

Some concerns to be addressed
>The lack of bibliography
These papers have been translated from my mother tongue into english. All bibliography is was kept and will be added in due time, my intent is to write 10 or so documents just like these. The choice of words for the reference section is to be taken as a joke, it will be discarded.
>The emphasis on contextualization
Occult philosophy is inherently axiomatic, yet all traditions differ in their interpretation. I think it is important to look at the history of the subject and familiarize the reader with the material before going deep into abstraction. I cite authors and name their works when imperative.
>The choice of formalism used
Even though magic itself is axiomatic, we must keep in mind two very important things. That these axioms can be expressed in all manner of different formalisms and that this is an elusively empirical science.
The ideas discussed in these documents are expressed in the language of differential geometry and will be further developed in that of algebraic topology.
>The deterministic idealization
I hope that after reading the papers you will come to understand that the even the general notions of this matter are incompatible with non deterministic descriptions of what is or what it will be. This allows calculations to become intuitive, yet burdens us with the responsibility of giving a reason to the apparent randomness in quantum measurements.

In a sense magic is all about moving information to different places, allowing it to have material consequences. Practical magic can roughly be divided into two branches:
>Projective
Creates a well defined set of information and aims to distribute it to another subset of the space where thoughts reside
>Receptive
Aims to catch particular information by establishing a relationship between what they aim to look for and the set that embodies it.

Practitioners of the first are what you may commonly think of as alchemists, ceremonial magicians, witches and the like. Those who study the second aspect are seers, readers and remote viewers.

What's your point even Anon? Why do you beat this dead horse so savagely and persistently?

It's a semantics marathon with you. A medical classification is just a tool. Like a diagnosis. No one disease, illness, injury or disorder is perfectly uniform in every single case. There's a plethora of underlying etiologies for many diseases, many diseases are widely accepted as a classified disease even when the etiology isn't understood. Some types of dementia are a good example, we only know there's a correlation between the buildup of beta amyloids and tau tangles and Alzheimer's but we don't know why. Are they the cause? A byproduct? A form of damage control by the brain anatomy? We just don't know yet. But that doesn't mean Alzheimer's isn't a disease.

It's the same with mental illnesses. We do not classify them as diseases or illnesses or disorders based on perfect omniscient understanding of their etiologies. We classify them based on a pathosymptological diagnosis.

Calling a medical problem a "disease" or disability isn't about accurately describing the nature of the problem. It's about grouping similar cases into categories in order to facilitate collaboration between caretakers, patient handovers between facilities and individuals and to make planning a treatment course faster and more accurate.

Stop obsessing pedantically over this Anon. It's not healthy for you.

>>15064109
It's like the saying, you are the sum of the fife people closest to you. Same goes for the information you get. What is your input? What do you read, what do you watch?
If you're into maths or physics and have never read the words of the great mathematicians and physicists, then that's the mistake. And I don't talk about secondary and tertiary literature, I mean their original works. Have you read Euclid, have you read Euler, have you read Poincaré?
Same goes for every other field. Go to the source and get the knowledge without a filter. Try to cut out mediocre authors, just consume the brightest of old days and of today. They will inevitably influence you; even if you never get on their level, but even if you reach 5% of them you're already miles ahead of everyone else that learns from average people.

In whatever field you are, try to get the whole picture. You have to develop intuition for it, so that even if you see something new you already know the answer or at least know what you have to do. You have to gain complete mastery in a field, that will probably take you 10 years.

And then study another field as a hobby. But do it with the intention to gain deep understanding and recognize patterns. Maybe you will see connections between those fields, maybe you can create something completely new by connecting those fields.
For example, if you are a chemist and study computer science as a hobby, you could develop a software for chemist that could become the industry standard, because it's so much better than the alternatives. But there are so many ways to combine different fields. Don't give up, I believe in you.

posts.name: OP
posts.com:
>>14994421
here are several pieces of advice:
1) do not let anyone, especially a research advisor, to talk you into pursuing a topic because it is now trendy/easy to publish like AI/deep learning - been there, done that, currently regretting it
2) AI of any kind (especially deep learning) is all about the data, especially high quality data - even the best model will have shit performance if it does not have enough data to learn from
3) since doing the amount of experiments to generate sufficient amounts of data for deep learning is hardly feasible, you will almost certainly have to generate data by numerical computations (because analytical models either have very limited applicability or suck ass in most real-world scenarios) - if you are not skilled in those and/or do not have powerful enough computing hardware, dont even start, learning/doing computation on top of learning/doing AI will be the end of you like it is being the end of me right now
4) if possible, look for data that already exists, it has the benefit of you not needing to make it yourself (and that is a BIG plus)
5) have a plan B that can be feasible with the work you have done working for plan A if plan A fails

>>15003920
>>15003929
Anon, I think you should go through these papers >>14996209

The point of PINNs is that it requires sparse or no data to train. It is basically unsupervised learning.

The way it trains is that it uses the generalization of BackPropgation Algorithm which is known as Auto-Differentiation. So, after calculating the outputs (which are flow parameters like velocity, pressure etc) and then use auto-diff algorithm to calculate partial-derivatives with inputs which are space-time coordinates. So, in essence, we are trying to represent the PDEs without any FVM/FEM discretization.

On the other hand, you have pointed out correctly that the DL can only represent one instance of the boundary and initial conditions. But, some researchers have already used techniques like transfer learning to use pre-train models. Furthermore, some are even claming that they can create generalize model (https://arxiv.org/abs/2202.05476).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15004017
>>15004017
>no training data required - how?

Basically you segregate domain into 3 parts and represent them as a tuple of space and time (x,y,z,t). The three parts are the initial conditions (x,y,z,0), boundary conditions (0,t) and internal points (x,y,z,t).

For the initial and boundary conditions, you basically use the supervised strategy i.e. calculating MSE loss between predicted value and ground truth.

The "unsupervised" parts kicks in when for the interior points, you basically use the PDEs to "regularise" the solution.

>also, maybe you have some good step-by-step tutorials for a beginner?
There are many implementations available on github, but I would recommend looking into the DeepXDE library (https://deepxde.readthedocs.io/en/latest/). It explains this stuff using rigorous math.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm happy I found this thread. I have been looking into PINNs a lot recently and I struggle to see what's interesting with them.

Its a method to solve PDEs by incorporating the form of the PDE into the loss. There is not much novelty here in my opinion. First problem that some other anons pointed out is that they're data-driven. As with any DL algorithm they will not generalize well, you have no guarantees and you need to solve them yourself first (to generate the training data) to be able to train them. I don't have much knowledge about the application side but I've heard (from researchers in fluid dynamics) that standard numerical solvers are faster (this of course depends on what you want to do).

I can see two interesting parts that I'm currently pursuing. First problem is that they're data-driven. A better method - which is at the core of DL research - is building the biases you want (in this case constraints from a PDE) into the architecture. A lot has been done in incorporating group symmetries into NN (convolutional nets, g-convolutions, graph networks) - same can be done for physical laws (https://arxiv.org/abs/2210.01741)

The second is discovering the underlying PDE from data i.e. symbolic regression. This is more about using NNs to discover new governing laws or invariants from data. I find the idea very appealing, but it's very engineery and uninspired at this point. You don't have much mathematical guarantees as there will be infinitely many equations fitting your data. How to choose the correct one is an open problem.

posts.com: Source: My own PhD in data driven methods for fluids. Steve Brunton, George Karniadakis, Omer San and their kind are snake oil salesmen. They make the tiniest tweak in their ANN architecture, test it on 1D Burgers' or 2D Bossinesq flow, never report the cost of training the network, and call it a machine learning revolution. They have skewed incentives to peddle this stuff because DOE bureaucrats dont know how to recognize bullshit, and they know Congress wants to hear about investments in AI. The fact of the matter is that the money is better spent on stuff like high order DG, high-enthalpy solvers, and adaptive/automated meshing, but that isn't as sexy as machine learning in annual reports. PINNs are impossible to converge, SINDy is a solution looking for a problem, and everything else is just fancy curve fitting. I've been able to make a good career after my PhD on this stuff, but it is honestly just a lot of hot air and marketing.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14994421
I don't get how neural networks can possibly help with CFD simulations. Laminar flow simulations are basically a solved problem, so the only application is in turbulent flow simulations. But the basis of the utility of neural networks is that you train them on a shitton of data, and hope that your simulations are close enough to the training data so that your results are reasonably accurate. But this has two issues: first, you can never provide enough data so that any simulation you do resembles a training case, and second, turbulence is a fundamentally chaotic phenomenon. A tiny change in boundary or initial conditions can dramatically change the outcome of the simulation.

>>15024071

CompBio person here. While some people make specific model architectures and things like that for Biology, as someone with a background in Biology your best bet is in application of these algorithms to biological questions.

A piece of advice is to understand the uses of different kinds of AI in biology. Most AI used for biomarker and polygenic risk signatures is "classical" in the sense that it uses linear methods or decision trees. These methods are much more interpretable than deep learning models and so tend to be more trusted.

These methods (and classifiers in particular) are generally also used to aid in supervised understanding of disease drivers (as in train a classifier to tell the difference between two disease states with RNA-seq and look at what the important genes are).

Clustering and dimension reduction algorithms are also important. You should understand transformation methods like PCA, UMAP and TSNE very well.

Multiple omics integration for drug/drug target discovery is often being driven by learned matrix facrorisation algorithms.

Deep learning is making inroads in a couple of key areas. Variational autoencoders have shown great success as dimension reduction methods and beat traditional methods like PCA in terms of ability to filter out noise in large data sets (like single cell experiments).

Image analysis people who know image neural networks are an increasingly large part of the industry since Spatial Transcriptomics has come in.

People are also trying to apply some of the work being done in Causal modelling using Bayesian networks, and recent developments in graph neural networks are hyped to speed make this easier, but nobody has shown shit worth taking seriously yet.

You mean basically screen drugs against various tissues/ bugs, catalogue the features of the drugs/the organoids response and then use that to predict the best ones?

It's a cool approach. What it lacks is systems context. As the efficacy of drugs in a biological system will be effected by feedback loops involving tissues your organoid won't be in contact with then there will always be effects and variables that will decrease your drugs chances of success when moved to a real system (i.e a human body). People are beginning to account for this with these super complex interconnected cell population experiments, where they like have a network of cells in dishes with controlled flows between types of cells to allow experiments to control for cell type interactions and feedback loops beyond what you could get for a simple organoid, but that research (as you said) is early days and pretty academic.

Nobody trusts just in vitro evidence as evidence of efficacy yet as these systems are unproven.

The last approach gets the best results right now.

With neural networks you always need to define your training set as having an input and a label. If you can do that, you can train. Your input can be whatever you want. Shove all of those into input tensors and then shove your desired end state in your label tensor.

Periodic boundaries just means that all pairs of opposite boundaries have to coincide up to some level of accuracy at every simulation step, no? That's literally it.

>>15060792
Your dataset should be representative of the domain you are interested in. That means, if necessary different ICs and BCs that span the whole domain that you are interested in. The neural network then learns an approximation of the physics i.e. navier-stokes, free surface interactions, ...etc. Then you can setup a new simulation with a specific IC and BC which did not appear in the training dataset but which are part of the domain represented by the training dataset. Then you can infer this simulation much faster (because it is linear math) than it would take to compute it.
So in PINNs and in the unconstrained Deep Learning approaches, you are training a physics engine which can generalize to some extent over many ICs and BCs as long as they are within the domain represented by the training dataset.

Operator learning is also possible, but I am not an expert, the field is newer and from what I can tell, it is even harder to get real world simulations of such an approach for now.

>>15065682
You need to understand that nobody has ever isolated an HIV virus particle (or rather a homogenous sample including nothing but HIV virions). Unless you have isolated the entity, you cannot claim its existence, cannot prove that its virulent and infectious etc. from a purely logical standpoint. If you're not working with an isolated entity, then:
>What about electron micrographs of HIV
These are photos of a decaying culture zoomed on a certain spherical particle. You don't know that the cytopathic effect was caused by this entity, that the sequenced genome (see later) belongs to this entity etc. The entities could be exosomes or extracellular vesicles whose presence is caused by the experiment itself, you have simply no way of knowing.
>the sequence of the viral genome of HIV
If you're not sequencing from an isolated entity but from a mixture of genetic material of various origins, you have no idea that the obtained genome truly belongs to an entity found in a human body, and is not just a random string of various RNA/DNA segments present in the culture.
It took like 10 years to reach a consensus about the genome of the measles virus. They haven't isolated the virus and read the genome in its entirety. They've identified many many short segments of genetic information from the cellular debris and argued for 10 years about what should and shouldn't be part of the genome. Nobody has ever checked whether the sequence they've agreed upon can be truly found in the nature.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15065682
>The isolation and characterization of HIV reverse-transcriptase and integrase
Same problem. The enzymes are not isolated from purified viral particles, ergo you have no way of knowing their origin. Nowadays, you can even download the HIV genome from the internet, look for the genes in question, and do everything synthetically without any sort of verification that similar processes occur in vivo. You can make research about the enzymes without ever taking a sample from an HIV patient. Clearly these abstract methods need to be based on solid grounds, but they aren't since the virus has never been isolated.
>finding HIV in GRIDS patients
Nobody has ever isolated a virus particle from a patient's sample, virologists themselves say that the samples contain "too little virus", so that culturing has to take place before we can see it. Which gets us to
>culturing HIV collected from patients?
The cytopathic effect, which is the supposed proof of the virus infecting other cells, occurs even without the presence of a pathogen. The culturing procedure ends with a cellular debris from which viral particles are NOT isolated (in the sense that you would end up with a homogenous sample). This debris is then photographed (see above) and a genome is sequenced from it (see above). Neither of these say anything unless you're working with an isolated entity.

>https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2895164/ Here. And there are thousands of studies like it
This paper provides a perfect example of what I'm talking about. Instead of working with an isolated virus, they are studying biochemical processes in cell cultures that were inoculated with a virus obtained by the inconclusive methods explained above. The belief that the inoculated substance contains pathogenic particles and that the observed effects have anything to do with what happens inside the human body is completely baseless.

When someone says that "consciousness is an illusion," they are suggesting that the subjective experience of being aware, or having a sense of self, is not a fundamental aspect of reality. Instead, they may argue that consciousness is simply a byproduct of the functioning of the brain and its underlying neural processes, and that our experience of being conscious is an illusion created by these processes.

This view is based on the idea that the brain is essentially a complex information processing system, and that our subjective experience of consciousness arises as a result of the operation of this system. According to this view, the brain is responsible for creating the illusion of consciousness by integrating information from various sensory modalities and creating a unified experience of the world.

However, the idea that consciousness is an illusion is highly controversial and is not widely accepted in the scientific community. There is ongoing debate about the nature of consciousness and how it arises from the brain's activity, and it is likely that a complete understanding of consciousness will require the development of new scientific theories and approaches.

Yes, this is a GPT response :^)

>>15069460
paradox-free time travel is indeed physically feasible, but there's no requirement to avoid interactions
the series Dark is a great example, where characters interact with their younger and older selves all the time
the only necessity is that causality is preserved, so you can't change the past at all, only affect it in the exact way that led up the present
this is known as a causal loop, and as long as it obeys that principle, the Novikov self-consistency principle, it's perfectly fine

>Mainly just interested how deserts become forests over time. If the only change is water, sand has no real nutrients in it for forests to grow, yet they say the Nile used to be full of forestry.
It's cause and effect. If you were to plant a billion trees in the middle of Australia, and water those trees with desalinated ocean water you'd lose some sure, but the sand would eventually become full of nutrients.

Trees bring in insects and other animals. They eat, die, and shit, fertilizing the ground.

Also, you ever pickup a bunch of dead leaves as a kid? You can crumple them into dust. When you add the occasional rainfall to that leaf dust, you now have mud.

So you combine the dead leaves, dead animals, and manure, and eventually the ground soil transforms over time.

posts.name: sage
posts.com:
No it is true. Speed and gravity alter the rate at which we travel through time. Speed and gravitational pull both slow down time. So one can "travel into the future" by going into space and traveling very fast, or by hanging out by something that has lots of gravity.

Satellites in orbit around the earth experience a slightly different rate of time. This is important to know for engineers who need to synchronize clocks between computers on the Earth and computers on satellites. I am a programmer and I knew someone who wrote code for satellites that had to take that into account.

> The techies' belief-system can best be explained as a religious phenomenon,[30] to which we may give the name "Technianity." It's true that Technianity at this point is not strictly speaking a religion, because it has not yet developed anything resembling a uniform body of doctrine; the techies' beliefs are widely varied.[31] In this respect Technianity probably resembles the inceptive stages of many other religions.[32] Nevertheless, Technianity already has the earmarks of an apocalyptic and millenarian cult: In most versions it anticipates a cataclysmic event, the Singularity,[33] which is the point at which technological progress is supposed to become so rapid as to resemble an explosion. Technianity has a favored minority—the Elect—consisting of the techies (equivalent to the True Believers of Christianity or the Proletariat of the Marxists[35]). Chess is a game for midwits that like to pretend they're intelligent. The only two things required to get really good at chess are:
1. Be able to play moves in your head quickly and accurately so that you can calculate whether a move is a good or not. This skill is genetic and has nothing to do with intelligence.
2. Play a shit ton of games, especially when you're a kid to develop intuition, this is the ability to look at a board and have a feeling for what the best move is(has nothing to do with intelligence). Although you need to calculate whether the move is actually good or not.

posts.com:
How did this random and obscure figure suddenly appear one day and achieve so much? Even claiming to have "proved" God.
I've been trying to collect his work, but most of it is just indigestible fragments
Take this deeply paraphrased work of his:
Suppose, as one might, nothing.
Which might be defined as 0, which can be seen as an existential structure. Regardless, it indicates the measure of a unit: 1.
And therefore it follows that 2 might exist, and it can be called chaotic or paradoxical induction.
This was me organizing as much as I could, maybe you might find it disingenuous to use my own words but it's more comprehensible.
This troubles me constantly, what does it mean that 0 -> 1?
I know that he's not saying that 0 = 1
I think it is more that [math]0, 1 \in S[/math]
Where S is some kind of structure that represents the proposed universe: supposed nothing.
I think greatly that Enoch's "genius" is more accidental derived from his obvious schizophrenia making believable claims even at times saying things and organizing symbols in completely nonsensical ways.
ITT I hope to discuss more the topic of Enoch
Enoch's Parable: https://pastebin.com/r2CqShsY

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Some more basic info: It seems that at times he didn't post under any name at all, then as the pseudonym Enoch and then Not Enoch for some odd reason.
It appears that most of his ideas descended from a very early approach to mathematics, possibly being unfamiliar with set theory and proofs.
In his early posts he was 18, though possibly younger.
This age would be consistent with his lack of certain formal elements of mathematics.
However, he may have been an accelerated student because he also seemed to be interested with series.
An early observation was that [math]\sum_{n>0}{1/2^n}[/math] converges to 1. And later it he seemed to have noticed that [math]\sum_{n>0}{1/k^n} = 1/(k-1)[/math]
He then came to the conclusion that, I would say famously in terms of his writings, 1 = 1/n + 1/n +... and that as n approached 0 that 1 = 0 + 0 +...
Which with this result he said that it would be nonsensical to claim that 1 = 0, but rather that 0*infinity = 1 (other rather as I would add |0*infinity| = 1). While this result does seem to make sense it's really an example of notational abuse.
To which seems to have opened up a chapter of his madness.
Another note about him, he seemed to have fervently hated imaginary numbers, referring to "believers of imaginary numbers" as "imagicucks" or "imagitards"

>>15069320
Soil itself is fairly complex. it consists of course of sand, minerals, and clays. However, it also should consist of organic matter (both large and small), bacteria, carbon deposits, and moisture. All of which are needed for plants to grow healthily. In modern tilling agriculture, the soil is aerated which promotes two factors, combustion which causes co2 to be released into the atmosphere as well as the accelerated breakdown of organic matter and more rapid evaporation of water, and, plow pan which is a hard compact layer that forms under tilled soil in response to tilling which makes the ground much less permeable to water reducing the ability of aquifers to replenish and also interferes with the soil's ability to hold water. Because of these two things, more irrigation and fertilizer is required to even grow anything. If you need consistent application of fertilizers just to get something to grow as is the case in the US Midwest and various other areas which have been regularly, the soil is practically already dead.

>high-range IQ tests are legit
IQ is a normalized ranking system. That is an IQ test is designed to give a test taker a score that is only meaningful relative to other test takers and the assignment of scores is designed/adjusted to fit a normal distribution. It's questionable as to whether or not the normal-range IQ tests actually represent intelligence. This is much like a normalized grading system in a university course may not actually represent the knowledge of a student immediately after completing the course. That of course, implies that these high-range IQ tests may have even less to do with intelligence than the normal ranged IQ tests.

That being said, contrary to the hype found in this thread. Langan is a loser. What has he done other than write a book and a couple of papers on virtually nothing? As for Rick Rosner, what has he done other than write smut for tv shows? He's also a loser. Neither of them have done anything meaningful with their alleged intelligence.

Compare either of them to someone like Faraday who, in spite of having little formal education and mostly self-educated, made significant contributions to both chemistry and electromagnetism, and hence furthered the development of human sciences and technology. If Langan is as intelligent of an autodidact as claimed, why hasn't he attempted to match this in his spare time. Surely someone who claims to have studied advanced mathematics in his spare time and spent a lot of time thinking about the nature of the universe can at least provide something tangible relevant to the fundamental theories of physics or solve a few difficult math problems that would yield publishable results that could lead to meaningful developments.

posts.com:
>>14938339
>Is there a definitive physics text for undergraduate calculus based physics 1 and 2?
No, they're all more or less the same. The standard in my state when I did my undergrad was Halliday, Resnik, and Krane. The standard at the school I'm teaching at is Serway. For better or worse every intro physics sequence follows basically the same pattern: Physics I - mechanics and thermo, Physics II - E&M and modern. And all the books go through basically the same structure and routine for introducing topics:
You start with kinematics because it's the basis for all the vector and calculus language you're going to be using for describing motion later on, then forces and the laws of motion as a setup for the rest of linear dynamics (work and energy, impulse and momentum, etc). Then rotational motion, equilibrium, and dynamics to gradually introduce and build up the background needed to describe and combine translation and rotation. Then fluids, thermo, waves, sound.

E&M starts out by introducing charge and Coulomb's Law, basic integration methods for Gauss's Law/Poisson's Equation, circuits, more circuits, magnetic fields, forces, and induction, Faraday and Ampere, really gross Biot-Savart Law integration, then EM waves, optics, and a smidge of modern stuff if there's time.

Some undergraduate courses do a four-course sequence where they split off all the thermal stuff into one semester and all the quantum/relativity stuff into another, but I think the most common practice now is to give thermal the short end of the stick and lump contemporary topics into a Physics III or a Modern Physics course.

tl;dr - Just pick whatever's cheapest or whatever you can pirate easiest.

posts.com:
>>15034298
No, it's actually a terrible list that will demotivate you. Several of the "prerequisite" books there are more advanced than the "final" calculus books.

If you're starting below a basic highschool level you will be much better off with a highschool level text, or something like khanacademy if you need immediate feedback drills. Look to see if any local schools run adult remedial classes if you're really serious. Especially when you're just starting out it's very useful to have access to an instructor.

If you can handle highschool algebra and geometry well enough, I like Epp's Discrete Mathematics for a gentle first introduction to more abstract "mathy" mathematics. It's very well presented and should be accessible to a motivated student, even if their background is a little weak.

>>15055344
>What can be done about science not being perceived as glamorous?
Promote the achievements and successes of scientists: Highlighting the contributions that scientists have made to society can help to make science more glamorous and show the important role that it plays in our lives.

Make science more accessible: Many people may feel intimidated by science and feel like it is not for them. Making science more accessible and approachable, through activities like science festivals and demonstrations, can help to make it more appealing to a wider audience.

Encourage media coverage of science: Science-related news and events can often be overlooked in favor of more sensational headlines. Encouraging media outlets to cover science stories can help to make it more visible and appealing to a wider audience.

Support science education: Providing students with access to high-quality science education can help to spark their interest in the subject and encourage them to pursue careers in science.

Show the diversity of science: Science is not just for a select few, and showcasing the diversity of people who work in the field, including people of different genders, races, and backgrounds, can help to make it more attractive and inclusive.

>>15055284
Chemistry but I've heard the same from engineers and other scientists. We have a group of high schoolers coming through the labs for a tour in a month and the teams have been brainstorming ways to discourage them from our fields (managers don't know this).
I'm biased because I live in Australia where there's few opportunities so the job market here sucks and pays poorly for a lot of work.
I did an accelerated undergrad so my first year was compressed into ~6 months and I did an advanced degree so my last year was research based. No masters required to go into a PhD if you already have a research degree/experience here.
In general science and engineering jobs here suck. And I mean "even with dual incomes a bank will never give enough to get a mortgage within a 1 hour commute of anywhere with jobs no matter how many degrees you have" kind of suck. There's some exceptions if you don't mind doing FIFO or transferring into non-science/engineering roles but then I don't really count those roles as being based on your degree since you could get there with less time and money wasted.

Honestly I'm just salty because work has been extra shit recently and I look at my friends/family who never even graduated but self-taught programming who now make more than my boss' boss and think I should have stuck to keeping science as a hobby and done something else to earn money.
I knew I'd never be making money but I thought I would at least be comfortably able to live and research things that interest me. My goal now is to grind the 5 more years that I need until my assets are enough to be financially independent through passive income and then I can work fulltime on the research I'm interested in but pays less than my rent (again, my wife and I will never be able to afford a house here until we retire and move away from where the jobs are).

>>15055284
>I would like to do research later.
>Is it just because its hard to get a job / to get a position or is the work bad?
not him but I also did chemistry and now work in research in industry. It's doable but you should be aware that it's certainly not the easiest path towards earning a comfortable living, assuming that's what you care about the most. I consider myself lucky that I managed to get a research position straight after a masters. I earn a decent enough salary for my age and where I live (although that's UK so most wages are shit), but nothing exceptional. I could have earned more doing some generic shit like engineering, comp sci, finance or whatever, with a less competitive job market and less occupational hazards to boot - although the latter is part of the fun if you ask me.
The work is enjoyable but this depends a lot on where you work and how much you enjoy your field of study. As for difficulty getting a job, I'd say you need to be top 25% of your cohort grade-wise, and make a real effort to get some form of internship before you graduate for there to be any sort of guarantee.

Prime numbers are weird.

1. Every even composite number can be expressed as the sum of 2 primes. Why? Nobody knows.
2. Every odd number greater than or equal to 7 can be expressed as the sum of 3 primes.
3. The number of primes before n can be estimated with 1/ln(n).
4. Infinite series of primes usually relate to pi somehow or the even numbers.
5. Every number can be expressed as the product of some number of primes.
6. Most claims on prime numbers rely on an unproven 200-year-old hypothesis.
7. The primes are somehow related to the zeta function too.

There's not really a simple pattern either, the most simple pattern in the primes is that n is prime if it is a factor of (n-1)!+1.

I feel like I can't truly understand the universe until I understand the primes. And nobody understands the primes so I feel like nobody truly understands the universe yet.

Take a bunch of small beads and put them in a square device that doesn’t allow beads to stack. So you can move them around and change the length and width. The challenge is to determine if the number of beads is a prime number. To do this, you would have to manipulate the device and check all possible dimensions, first starting with a length/width of 2, then 3, then 5, etc. This simple task shows why the primes are so hard to understand. You have to brute force it.

the world is constantly changing and evolving through a process of dialectical development. This means that the world is made up of opposing forces and ideas that interact and struggle with each other, leading to the emergence of new, higher-level concepts and forms of reality.

In this view, the idea that we may be living in a simulation is itself a product of dialectical development. The concept of a simulation arises out of the opposition between the objective reality that we perceive and the subjective reality that we experience. As we come to understand more about the nature of reality and the ways in which it can be manipulated and simulated, the concept of a simulation becomes a higher-level concept that incorporates and transcends these opposing ideas.

the idea that we may be living in a simulation is itself a product of the ongoing process of dialectical development, and as such, it is not a definitive or absolute truth. Instead, it is a concept that emerges out of the interaction and opposition of different ideas and forces, and it will continue to evolve and change as our understanding of reality and its nature develops.

>>15028618
Yes, this is essentially settled science in many respects, but not in the way most people think it is.

"You," to the extent you are a single, unified thing (there is plenty of evidence against this position, but we can go with it for now), simulate/hallucinate your surroundings.

You don't see your room "as it is itself," you see your room based on a rendering made via computation. Pic related is decent as an intro on this but misses two key things:

A. The amount of information in our enviornment absolutely dwarfs what comes into the nervous system. Deacon's Towards a Science of Biosemiotics explores the relationship between thermodynamic/Boltzmann Entropy and information/Shannon Entropy pretty well (shorter paper, not a book). Any organism can only bring in a fantastically small amount of information about their enviornment without succumbing to entropy.

The sensory organs and systems we have are shaped by evolution to show us fitness playoffs, not truth. Colors and smells don't exist sans life. These are encodings of information based on survival value. Example, there are three primary colors because we have three color sensing cells; if we evolved from birds we'd see all different colors from 4 primaries).

Of the small amount of information our organs do take on, the overwhelming amount is dropped. Experience is overwhelmingly the result of computation, not information taken from outside the body. We amplify patterns useful to survival and drop information that isn't. So reality very much is simulated.

This is why optical illusions work so well, why you don't experience the blind spot in your vision where your optic nerve enters the eye, and why some stimuli become unnoticeable after prolonged exposure. Also why sensory deprivation can result in realistic hallucinations; it's mostly computation anyhow.

3D linear space time is just another of these survival based models...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15033273
...although we take space time more seriously because touch, sight, hearing, and balance all feed into one model. However, at the end of the day it is just a model.

B. Our inherited model of space and time, and of discrete objects, absolutely falls apart at very small and very large scales. This is why quantum mechanics and relatively seem so unintuitive. Our simulation wasn't "designed" around these scales.

Now, Hoffman's book is a very good critique of why naive realism about the external world is wrong, but in the last chapter he totally switches gears and looks for a solution.

He asks what Fichte asked if Kant's noumenal world (the world of objective things as they are themselves, as opposed to the phenomenal world of experience): "what posit this thing we can never know directly exists at all?" After all, if we can never truly know it, and our scientific models always exist within first person experience, within cognition, why introduce the philosophical and unknowable. His solution is less convincing than the complaint though.

Another thing to consider is that many physicists consider information to be on par with energy and matter as ontologically fundemental. Others consider information to be ontologically fundemental and matter and energy to just be things that emerge from information.

There are two ways to take this really because information can be seen as something objective that exists as a physical property, or something only coherent if you have a receiver of said information. The second view doesn't necessarily entail idealism, it just says that things only exist relationally, not "as they are themselves" in some sort of "view from nowhere."

Further developments in QM, non-locality and (less proven) contextuality (see recent modified Wigner's Friend experiments done with photons) make me think that the most common paradigm for the sciences, the idea of a coherent "objective view from nowhere/anywhere" will need to be replaced...

TL;DR, you definitely live in experienced reality. >>15033736
There is an interesting idea here. Let's say that it is possible to fully describe the universe over time symbolically. This doesn't seem like a stretch given the universe seems to be made of discrete things that could be symbolized, and we do have means for dealing with continuous variables as well.

If this is true, than you could indeed describe the universe completely in a very, very large "book."

Now let's just assume MWI is true. No problem. You just need an even larger book that has the results to every outcome.

How would you code such a thing? Well let's assume it requires some really strange math we don't have yet, making it easiest to lay out (conceptually for ourselves at least) using 10,000 different symbols/operators.

If this book could exist, if you say such a thing is possible, then a simple program that randomly picks each of the 10,000 symbols, then picks another, then another... etc., running on an infinite Turing Machine, would eventually produce that book.

It would also produce a LOT of gibberish. But the program would be incredibly, incredibly short, that is despite producing every possible proofs, a model of our universe and all possible outcomes in it, etc.

The problem here is that, we generally think of information as additive. When I have a program that stimulates chess and another for checkers, the two together have more information (algorithmic). But the simple infinite symbol program produces all programs despite having very little information.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15033946
>>15033946
But of course, all 10,000 symbols could be described in binary, so really you only need a program spewing random 1s and 0s.

So if you look at a description of information like Wheeler's, it is clearly wrong. The information content of something isn't all the true / false questions you need to fully describe it. It's all the true/false questions needed to specify what a thing is not. You can't talk about the information content of protons because they have no information content unless you have a void where there aren't protons to the measurement to.

The algorithmic information content can't be the shortest possible description of a string, since a random generator will eventually produce all programs. It is the shortest possible description that rules out all other possible programs.

The truth of the matter is that we know things when we’re not here that we choose to forget while we are here. You know everything about what your life's going to be like here, from beginning to end. You knew it before you got here, and you'll know it again when you leave here, but while you're here you’re focused on it, and you're focused on each given moment in it. And when you leave here, it all comes rushing back and you say, 'Of course, yes!' And if you made the analogy that your life was like a movie that you made, where you picked all of the characters and the actors to play in your movie and you wrote the script out and said this is what I want to have happen and how I want it to be, it would be a very good analogy."

The concept of simulating a universe has been explored in both science and science fiction, and while it is purely theoretical at this point, it raises many interesting questions about the nature of time and reality.

In a deterministic universe, all events are determined by their causes, and if we had perfect knowledge of the state of the universe at a given time, we would be able to predict all future events with certainty. If such a universe were being simulated by a slow processor, the simulated experience of time for the inhabitants of the universe would be the same as if it were running at a faster speed. In other words, the inhabitants of the simulated universe would not be able to tell the difference between a fast and a slow simulation.

However, it is important to note that this is purely a theoretical concept and there is currently no evidence to suggest that our universe is being simulated in this way.

>§87] But this mere Being, as it is mere abstraction, is therefore the absolutely negative; which, in a similarly immediate aspect, is just Nothing.

Here the argument is that, because the concept of Being is very abstract and so without much content (a privation), it is rather like the concept of Not Being, also without much content, which means that it implies Not Being, so that things of which Being is predicated, like the Absolute, must also be predicated with Not Being. This is like an argument that because fire engines are red, and red is rather like pink, therefore fire engines are pink.

How any sane, let alone sensible, person could take such an argument seriously is astonishing. posts.name: Strange Love
